verses.text: Now there happened to be a troublemaker there whose name was Sheba the son of Bichri, a Benjaminite. He blew the trumpet and said, 'We have no share in David, nor inheritance in the son of Jesse! Every man to his tents, Israel!'
verses.comment: The phrase 'troublemaker' translates the Hebrew 'worthless man' (Ish Belial), keeping the negative connotation but in contemporary form.

verses.text: So all the men of Israel withdrew from David and followed Sheba the son of Bichri. But the men of Judah stayed with their king, from the Jordan all the way to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Translation as in original; 'all the men of Israel' refers to the northern tribes; language is clear.

verses.text: When David came to his house at Jerusalem, the king took the ten concubines whom he had left to care for the house and put them in custody. He provided for them, but he did not go in to them. So they were kept shut up until the day of their death, living as widows.
verses.comment: Rendering preserves the meaning. 'He did not go in to them' is a literal translation of the Hebrew idiom for sexual relations.

verses.text: Then the king said to Amasa, 'Summon the men of Judah to me within three days, and be here yourself.'
verses.comment: Direct command as in Hebrew.

verses.text: So Amasa went to summon Judah, but he delayed beyond the set time that he had been appointed.
verses.comment: Modern English for 'tarried longer than the set time'.

verses.text: And David said to Abishai, 'Now Sheba the son of Bichri will do us more harm than Absalom. Take your lord's servants and go pursue him, so he does not find fortified cities and escape from us.'
verses.comment: Translation maintains clarity in modern English.

verses.text: So Joab's men went out after him, with the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and all the mighty men. They left Jerusalem to pursue Sheba the son of Bichri.
verses.comment: Groups named as in Hebrew; 'mighty men' is literal rendering of 'Gibborim'.

verses.text: When they were at the great stone that is in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Now Joab was wearing a belt with a sword fastened at his waist in its sheath. As he went forward, the sword fell out.
verses.comment: Describes Joab's action as literal as possible.

verses.text: Joab said to Amasa, 'Is it well with you, my brother?' And Joab took Amasa by the beard with his right hand as if to kiss him.
verses.comment: Literal actions and greeting as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: But Amasa did not notice the sword in Joab's hand. So Joab struck him in the stomach and spilled his entrails to the ground, without striking him again, and he died. Then Joab and Abishai his brother pursued Sheba the son of Bichri.
verses.comment: Describes the killing in direct, literal language.

verses.text: And one of Joab's young men stood by Amasa and said, 'Whoever favors Joab and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab!'
verses.comment: Literal call to the troops; pronoun made singular for clarity.

verses.text: Amasa lay wallowing in his blood in the middle of the road. When the man saw that all the people stopped, he moved Amasa from the road into the field and threw a garment over him, because he saw that everyone who came by stopped.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering; 'wallowing' is accurate; other details kept direct.

verses.text: When he was taken out of the road, everyone went on after Joab to pursue Sheba the son of Bichri.
verses.comment: Literal, straightforward language.

verses.text: Sheba passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel of Beth-maacah. And all the Bichrites assembled and followed him in.
verses.comment: 'All the Bichrites assembled' is literal, meaning Sheba's clan followed him.

verses.text: And all the men who were with Joab came and besieged him in Abel of Beth-maacah. They built a siege ramp against the city, and it stood against the outer wall. And all the people with Joab were battering the wall, trying to bring it down.
verses.comment: Literal military details retained. 'Siege ramp' for 'mound' or 'bank' (Hebrew 'solelah').

verses.text: Then a wise woman called from the city, 'Listen! Listen! Tell Joab, "Come here, so I may speak to you."'
verses.comment: Speech preserved as quoted in Hebrew.

verses.text: He approached her, and the woman said, 'Are you Joab?' He answered, 'I am.' Then she said to him, 'Listen to the words of your servant.' And he said, 'I am listening.'
verses.comment: Dialogue kept direct and literal.

verses.text: She said, 'They used to say in former times, "Let them seek counsel at Abel," and so they settled disputes.'
verses.comment: Proverbial saying rendered in plain English.

verses.text: 'I am one of the peaceful and faithful in Israel. You seek to destroy a city that is a mother in Israel. Why will you swallow up the LORD’s inheritance?'
verses.comment: Metaphors 'mother in Israel' and 'LORD's inheritance' left intact as in Hebrew.

verses.text: Joab answered, 'Far be it, far be it from me, that I should swallow up or destroy!'
verses.comment: 'Far be it' translates the Hebrew idiom 'chalilah li.'

verses.text: That is not true. But a man from the hill country of Ephraim, called Sheba the son of Bichri, has lifted up his hand against King David. Hand him over, and I will withdraw from the city.' The woman said to Joab, 'Look, his head will be thrown to you over the wall.'
verses.comment: 'Hand him over' is a literal imperative.

verses.text: Then the woman went to all the people with her wise counsel. They cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bichri and threw it out to Joab. So he blew the trumpet, and they dispersed from the city, each to his tent. Joab returned to Jerusalem to the king.
verses.comment: Events rendered as plainly as possible.

verses.text: Now Joab was over all the army of Israel; Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and the Pelethites;
verses.comment: Official titles consistent with previous passages.

verses.text: Adoram was over the forced labor; Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was recorder;
verses.comment: Titles modernized for clarity. 'Forced labor' is literal.

verses.text: Sheva was secretary; Zadok and Abiathar were priests;
verses.comment: 'Sheva' reflects Hebrew spelling; official titles consistent.

verses.text: And Ira the Jairite was David’s priest.
verses.comment: 'David's priest' or chief minister; there is debate about the exact function.
